stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on polishing a sub-area in Course 11, 'Oily Boily Bay,' by fixing bugs and adding new dynamic 'hydraulic' platforms to enhance the industrial theme. The stream included live problem-solving of a texture memory issue with artist Biobak, discussions of future plans for an original game and Kickstarter, and reflections on game design philosophy and content creation.

development_findings.summary: The project is planned to have 15 courses and is estimated to be 75-80% complete, with bug-fixing underway for a future beta test.
Kaze had to devise a solution using a non-standard 96x42 texture resolution to fit an artist's detailed texture within the N64's strict 4096-byte texture memory limit.
development_findings.quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen.

development_findings.summary: Progress on certain elements, like fixing door animations, is blocked by the development of a new quaternion-based animation system by team member Lilaa, highlighting a key technical dependency.
development_findings.quote: Until we have Lila's quaternion animation exporter, R.I.P. Lila, we cannot fix the doors.

development_findings.summary: The design choice to return players to the hub world upon death is intentional, meant to make death feel more consequential and give players agency over their next action.
development_findings.quote: I prefer the player going back to the hub before the level. Because then you can still decide to go somewhere else. It also feels more impactful, more definite, more like you died.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is adding dynamic hydraulic platforms to an industrial area, programming them with variable speeds and randomized timings to create a chaotic, mechanical atmosphere.
The game is designed to minimize friction for the player, booting directly into a 3D file select level inspired by Super Mario Sunshine.
development_findings.quote: The game boots you directly into the file select. The game doesn't waste your time. That is important to me.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a visual glitch with platform rendering order, tracing it to a one-frame delay and fixing it by changing the object update priority in the code.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes modern games are designed as time-wasters rather than for providing meaningful experiences, a philosophy that directly influences his own design choices.
context_findings.quote: Modern game design is made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time. Not for people that want to go have an experience.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to leverage the release of RTYI to launch a Kickstarter for a new, original commercial game developed in Unreal Engine, aiming for financial independence.
context_findings.quote: Simultaneously with the release of Return to Yoshi's Island we are going to start a Kickstarter for this game in Unreal Engine and then we will make big money and then we will be able to just make whatever we want.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intends to properly compensate the project's musician and release the soundtrack as a physical album on a custom N64 cartridge that functions as a music player.
context_findings.quote: I feel like when RTYI releases, I want to pay the musician to have the rights to the music and then release an album for RTYI. I think that would be very fun. And the album would be like an N64 cartridge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's approach to difficulty is not to arbitrarily increase challenge, but to ensure that any difficult section is justified by how 'cool' or rewarding the required action is, leading to a natural difficulty curve.
context_findings.quote: I don't try to make the levels more difficult. I just put the threshold of how cool a jump has to be for it to be worth the difficulty lower... That way you automatically just end up with cool levels.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a full-time job as a programmer at Gears for Breakfast, the studio behind 'A Hat in Time'.
Kaze finds making YouTube content a chore and is primarily focused on game development, using his channel as a means to maintain an audience.
context_findings.quote: I'm just trying to keep my YouTube channel alive while I'm making this hack.

context_findings.summary: When discussing releasing a provocative mod for a sponsorship, Kaze jokes about Nintendo's potential reaction, indicating an awareness of but defiance towards the company's guidelines and legal posture.
context_findings.quote: Dude, Nintendo is going to have an aneurysm. Shigeru Miyamoto will just die from a heart attack when he sees that.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a high-resolution sail texture that exceeded the N64's memory limits, prompting a live, collaborative problem-solving session with Kaze to find a 'cursed' but functional resolution.
biobak.quote: Does this work for you, Biobak? This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. I think it works.

biobak.summary: Kaze requested a Blender file from Biobak to directly address the texture optimization issue, demonstrating a hands-on, collaborative workflow.

badub.summary: Kaze plans to pay Badub for the rights to the RTYI music to release it as a standalone album, showing a desire to ensure he is compensated for his work.

zeina.summary: Zeina confirmed Kaze's memory of a 'lost' mod ('Hot Tub Mario'), showing her long-term involvement and familiarity with his body of work.

key_stories.title: The Cursed Texture Resolution
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak worked together to solve a technical limitation where a detailed texture wouldn't fit in the N64's memory. Kaze devised a clever workaround by using a 'cursed,' non-standard texture resolution, exemplifying the unique challenges of retro game development.
key_stories.challenge: An artist, Biobak, created a sail texture that was too high-resolution for the N64's strict 4096-byte texture memory limit (TMEM), preventing it from being used in the game.
key_stories.process: Kaze first identified the memory overflow using his development tools. He then collaborated with Biobak live on stream, requesting the source file and experimenting with different compression formats and dimensions until he found a 'cursed' resolution that worked.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully fit the texture into memory by using a highly unconventional 96x42 pixel resolution, preserving the visual intent while adhering to the hardware's constraints. This showcased creative problem-solving under pressure.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the most cursed texture resolution I've ever seen. I think it works.

key_stories.title: The Lost 'Hot Tub Mario' Mod
key_stories.summary: Kaze rediscovered a 'lost' provocative mod he once made and, instead of letting it stay lost, devised a plan to release it as part of a major sponsorship. This story highlights his irreverent humor, his relationship with Nintendo's corporate image, and his savvy approach to content creation.
key_stories.challenge: While discussing a sponsorship, Kaze recalled a provocative mod he made called 'Hot Tub Mario 64' but realized he had no idea where the file was, believing it to be lost media.
key_stories.process: Kaze searched his files and DMs, confirming the mod's existence with his wife, Zeina. After failing to locate it easily, he brainstormed a new, provocative release strategy for it tied to a sponsorship from Honkai: Star Rail.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to embrace the mod's controversial nature, planning to unearth and release it as part of a sponsored video, cheekily framing it as a comment on Nintendo's creator guidelines.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, Nintendo is going to have an aneurysm. Shigeru Miyamoto will just die from a heart attack when he sees that.

key_stories.title: The 'Death' and Return of Lilaa
key_stories.summary: When a key animator, Lilaa, was absent for a week, Kaze and his community started a running joke that she had passed away. Her eventual return to the stream chat revealed the team's reliance on her work and the community's unique, dark sense of humor.
key_stories.challenge: Animator Lilaa, who is responsible for a critical new animation system, was absent from the community for a week, creating uncertainty and becoming a topic of discussion.
key_stories.process: Kaze and his viewers started a running gag that Lilaa had died, posting 'R.I.P. Lilaa' and discussing a memorial. This continued until she showed up in chat, leading to a humorous confrontation where they explained they had held a funeral for her.
key_stories.outcome: The situation resolved when Lilaa appeared in the stream chat, alive and well. The running joke underscored her importance to the project and the tight-knit, dark-humored nature of the development community.
key_stories.key_quote: I thought you died, Lilaa. Did you not see my post? R.I.P. Lilaa.

open_questions.topic: The Kickstarter and Unreal Engine Project
open_questions.context: Kaze announced a concrete plan to develop a demo for an original game in Unreal Engine and launch a Kickstarter for it concurrently with RTYI's release to fund future commercial projects.
questions: What was the moment you decided that this fan project, RTYI, would become the strategic springboard for your professional career in original game development?
How does the creative freedom of a ROM hack prepare you for the business realities of a Kickstarter and managing community expectations for a commercial product?
Without revealing secrets, what core design principles from RTYI do you feel are essential to carry over to your original game, and what do you want to leave behind?

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly stated that fixing certain bugs and implementing new animations (like for doors) is impossible until team member Lilaa finishes her 'quaternion animation exporter'.
questions: Can you explain in layman's terms what the quaternion animation system is and why it's such a critical upgrade for the project?
What new gameplay or aesthetic possibilities will this system unlock that were impossible in the original SM64 engine or with previous tools?
How do you manage a project's timeline and your own work when you have such a significant dependency on a single team member's technical breakthrough?

open_questions.context: Kaze articulated a strong critique of modern game design, stating it's made for 'depressed people' who want to 'erase time' rather than have a genuine 'experience'.
questions: Could you give some examples of modern games or mechanics that you feel exemplify this trend of being 'time erasers'?
What specific elements transform a game from a simple diversion into a meaningful 'experience' for you?
How have you intentionally designed RTYI's core loops and reward structures to actively combat this trend and foster a sense of 'experience'?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned his desire to pay the project's composer, Badub, for the music rights to release a physical soundtrack on a custom N64 cartridge that functions as an MP3 player.
questions: What was the inspiration behind the unique idea of a physical N64 cartridge album? What does it say about your view on the value of game music?
What is the process for composing a soundtrack that must feel authentic to the N64 era while also being original?
How does the collaborative process between a game designer and a composer work on a project like this? How is feedback given and incorporated?
